Full Reference: Castellanos-Morales, G., Paredes-Torres, L. M., Gámez, N., Hernández-Rosales, H. S., Sánchez-de la Vega, G., Barrera-Redondo, J., ... & Eguiarte, L. E. (2018). Historical biogeography and phylogeny of Cucurbita: Insights from ancestral area reconstruction and niche evolution. Molecular phylogenetics and evolution, 128, 38-54.

Data for tree estimation: nuclear (pepC) and plastid (ndhF and rpl32-trnL) markers
Note: de Medeiros, M. C. M., & Lohmann, L. G. (2015). Phylogeny and biogeography of Tynanthus Miers (Bignonieae, Bignoniaceae). Molecular phylogenetics and evolution, 85, 32-40.
Full Reference: de Medeiros, M. C. M. P., Guisan, A., & Lohmann, L. G. (2015). Climate niche conservatism does not explain restricted distribution patterns in Tynanthus (Bignonieae, Bignoniaceae). Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society, 179(1), 95-109.

Data for tree estimation: ITS and plastid (psbA-trnH, rpl16, trnL-rpl32, trnQ-rpS16)
Full Reference: de Oliveira Bünger, M., Fernanda Mazine, F., Forest, F., Leandro Bueno, M., Renato Stehmann, J., & Lucas, E. J. (2016). The evolutionary history of Eugenia sect. Phyllocalyx (Myrtaceae) corroborates historically stable areas in the southern Atlantic forests. Annals of botany, 118(7), 1209-1223.

Data for tree estimation: three nuclear loci, ITS+5.8S (White [237]), waxy (Peralta [174]) and lfy (Schultz [206])
Full Reference: Dupin, J., & Smith, S. D. (2018). Phylogenetics of Datureae (Solanaceae), including description of the new genus Trompettia and re-circumscription of the tribe. Taxon, 67(2), 359-375.

Data for tree estimation: Folk et al. 2017; although Folk et al. (2018) reported two calibrated trees treated under lognormal and truncated priors, we used the lognormal tree to keep consistence with other 18 studies because most of them estimated divergence times by applying the Bayesian relaxed molecular clock method with a lognormal distribution of rates.
Full Reference: Folk, R. A., Visger, C. J., Soltis, P. S., Soltis, D. E., & Guralnick, R. P. (2018). Geographic range dynamics drove ancient hybridization in a lineage of angiosperms. The American Naturalist, 192(2), 000-000.

Note: Dolichandra is centred in southern Brazil, northern Argentina and Paraguay (Lohmann & Taylor, 2014)
Full Reference: Fonseca, L. H. M., & Lohmann, L. G. (2015). Biogeography and evolution of Dolichandra (Bignonieae, Bignoniaceae). Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society, 179(3), 403-420.

Data for tree estimation: eight available plastid gene regions (matK, rbcL, trnV, ycf2, accD, rpl20, rpoB and rpoC1)
Method of time calibration: fossil calibrations following Leslie et al. (2012)
Note: Saladin, B., Leslie, A. B., Wüest, R. O., Litsios, G., Conti, E., Salamin, N., & Zimmermann, N. E. (2017). Fossils matter: improved estimates of divergence times in Pinus reveal older diversification. BMC evolutionary biology, 17(1), 95.
Full Reference: Gallien, L., Saladin, B., Boucher, F. C., Richardson, D. M., & Zimmermann, N. E. (2016). Does the legacy of historical biogeography shape current invasiveness in pines?. New Phytologist, 209(3), 1096-1105.

Data for tree estimation: four chloroplast (rbcL,matK, trnL-trnF, and ndhF) and three nuclear regions (ITS-I, ITS-II, and 26S)
Method of time calibration: no fossils, alternative rate calibrations and secondary calibrations
Full Reference: Gutiérrez-Valencia, J., Chomicki, G., & Renner, S. S. (2017). Recurrent breakdowns of mutualisms with ants in the neotropical ant-plant genus Cecropia (Urticaceae). Molecular phylogenetics and evolution, 111, 196-205.

Hipp, A. L., Manos, P. S., González‐Rodríguez, A., Hahn, M., Kaproth, M., McVay, J. D., ... & Cavender‐Bares, J. (2018). Sympatric parallel diversification of major oak clades in the Americas and the origins of Mexican species diversity. New Phytologist, 217(1), 439-452.

Method of time calibration: no Coccinia fossils, used a secondary calibration
Full Reference: Holstein, N., & Renner, S. S. (2011). A dated phylogeny and collection records reveal repeated biome shifts in the African genus Coccinia (Cucurbitaceae). BMC evolutionary biology, 11(1), 28.

Data for tree estimation: plastid (rbcL, matK, trnL, psbB, petB) and nuclear DNA (ITS, needly, leafy)
Full Reference: Larter, M., Pfautsch, S., Domec, J. C., Trueba, S., Nagalingum, N., & Delzon, S. (2017). Aridity drove the evolution of extreme embolism resistance and the radiation of conifer genus Callitris. New Phytologist, 215(1), 97-112.

Data for tree estimation: four chloroplast (matK, trnL-F, ycf1 and ndhF) and two nuclear regions (AP3 and phyA)
Full Reference: Li, P. S., Thomas, D. C., & Saunders, R. M. (2017). Historical biogeography and ecological niche modelling of the Asimina-Disepalum clade (Annonaceae): role of ecological differentiation in Neotropical-Asian disjunctions and diversification in Asia. BMC evolutionary biology, 17(1), 188.

Data for tree estimation: four plastid and three nuclear genes
Method of time calibration: secondarily calibrated based on the age obtained by Chomicki et al., 2015a, Chomicki et al., 2015b for Catasetinae’s crown group of 19.8 Ma
Full Reference: Martins, A. C., Bochorny, T., Pérez-Escobar, O. A., Chomicki, G., Monteiro, S. H., & de Camargo Smidt, E. (2018). From tree tops to the ground: reversals to terrestrial habit in Galeandra orchids (Epidendroideae: Catasetinae). Molecular phylogenetics and evolution, 127, 952-960.

Data for tree estimation: plastid petD and trnL loci and from nuclear encoded ITS and At1G13040 protein coding homologue
Full Reference: Nürk, N. M., Michling, F., & Linder, H. P. (2018). Are the radiations of temperate lineages in tropical alpine ecosystems pre‐adapted?. Global Ecology and Biogeography, 27(3), 334-345.

Data for tree estimation: chloroplast markers trnK–matK and ndhF and the nuclear marker phyC
Full Reference: Ogburn, R. M., & Edwards, E. J. (2015). Life history lability underlies rapid climate niche evolution in the angiosperm clade Montiaceae. Molecular phylogenetics and evolution, 92, 181-192.

Data for tree estimation: a nuclear ribosomal DNA marker (i.e., ITS) and seven chloroplast markers (i.e., psbA-trnH, trnL-F, rps16-trnQ, matK, ndhF, rbcL, and ycf1)
Full Reference: Ortiz-Rodriguez, A. E., Ornelas, J. F., & Ruiz-Sanchez, E. (2018). A jungle tale: Molecular phylogeny and divergence time estimates of the Desmopsis-Stenanona clade (Annonaceae) in Mesoamerica. Molecular phylogenetics and evolution, 122, 80-94.

Data for tree estimation: cpDNA rbcL, matK, trnL-F, psbA-trnH and the nuclear marker phytochrome C
Method of time calibration: two different secondary calibration points based on the Annonaceae-wide results of Pirie and Doyle [47]
Note: distributed in Central and South America; 14 species native to the Neotropics
Full Reference: Pirie, M. D., Maas, P. J., Wilschut, R. A., Melchers-Sharrott, H., & Chatrou, L. W. (2018). Parallel diversifications of Cremastosperma and Mosannona (Annonaceae), tropical rainforest trees tracking Neogene upheaval of South America. Royal Society open science, 5(1), 171561.

Data for tree estimation: five noncoding and three protein-coding plastid markers, one noncoding and one coding nuclear marker
Method of time calibration: a secondary calibration point obtained from Bouchenak-Khelladi et al. (2010)
Note: Humphreys, A. M., & Linder, H. P. (2013). Evidence for recent evolution of cold tolerance in grasses suggests current distribution is not limited by (low) temperature. New Phytologist, 198(4), 1261-1273.
Full Reference: Wüest, R. O., Antonelli, A., Zimmermann, N. E., & Linder, H. P. (2015). Available climate regimes drive niche diversification during range expansion. The American Naturalist, 185(5), 640-652.

Method of time calibration: two secondary calibration points based on Givnish et al. (2004)
Note: Wagner, N., Silvestro, D., Brie, D., Ibisch, P. L., Zizka, G., Weising, K., & Schulte, K. (2013). Spatio‐temporal evolution of Fosterella (Bromeliaceae) in the Central Andean biodiversity hotspot. Journal of Biogeography, 40(5), 869-880.
Full Reference: Paule, J., Wagner, N. D., Weising, K., & Zizka, G. (2017). Ecological range shift in the polyploid members of the South American genus Fosterella (Bromeliaceae). Annals of botany, 120(2), 233-243.
